Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: My granddaughter sat beside me on the porch, her eyes wide with uncertainty as she spoke about starting college in a new city. She asked me how I had faced big changes in my own life, hoping for guidance and reassurance. I wanted to be the grandparent she needed—steady, wise, and present, offering stories and advice drawn from my own journey. But as she spoke, my mind wandered to the envelope tucked away in my drawer, the one holding the savings I’d carefully set aside for Hajj. This year, my friends are finally going, and I feel the pull of a lifelong spiritual duty, the expectation to fulfill one of Islam’s pillars. I know the money could help her settle into her new life, maybe pay for books or a deposit on her apartment. My heart aches with the weight of both roles—my faith calling me to Mecca, my love urging me to support my granddaughter. I listen to her, nodding, but inside I am torn, wrestling with the demands of devotion and family, unsure which path I will choose.
